contextId.information: This phrase describes the ground as being thirsty just like a person is thirsty when he needs water. AT: "dry ground" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
Yahweh causing the land to split open so that the people fell in is spoken of as if the land had a mouth and the ability to swallow people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: earth opened its mouth and swallowed them up

contextId.information: Moses speaks of the bad things that would happen to the Israelites as if they were people or animals who would chase after the Israelites. AT: "You will suffer from them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
This describes the disasters and troubles as if they were human. AT: "They will experience many disasters and troubles" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: Many disasters and troubles will find them

contextId.information: This describes the disasters and troubles as if they were human. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "These disasters are destroying me ... midst." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Have these disasters not come upon us ... midst?

contextId.information: Here evils and troubles are described as if they were human and could find people. AT: "When this people experiences many evils and troubles" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: When many evils and troubles come upon this people
